	Renal vasoconstriction
	Systemic vasodilation
	Vasopressin release
	Cytokine release
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 4,2,3,1

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatorenal syndrome

Definition

Acute kidney injury in advanced liver disease

Pathophysiology

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of hepatorenal syndrome?

choices.text: Jaundice which begins in the sclera

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stepwise decrease in serum creatinine

 

Explanation:

Hepatorenal syndrome is characterized by a progressive increase in creatinine.

 

Clinical features of Hepatorenal syndrome:

Fatigue and lethargy

Initial symptoms

Loss of appetite

Due to increasing nausea

Jaundice

Begins in the sclera and progresses from head-to-toe. (Option B ruled out)

Coagulopathy

Impaired liver synthetic function, increasing the risk of bleeding. (Option D ruled out)

Ascites

Slow, gradual buildup of fluid in the peritoneum due to intravascular loss of albumin.

Hepatic encephalopathy

Confusion and altered mental status (Option C ruled out) as the liver fails to metabolize toxins.

Oliguria

Progressive decrease in urination frequency and volume as renal function deteriorates.

Creatinine

Stepwise progressive increase in creatinine (Option A)

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C presents with worsening ascites, oliguria, and fatigue. Physical examination reveals tense ascites, mild jaundice, and peripheral edema. Laboratory investigations show:

Serum creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL (baseline: 0.9 mg/dL)

Serum sodium: 126 mEq/L

Urine sodium: <10 mEq/L

Albumin infusion is planned as part of his management. What is the recommended dosage of albumin infusion for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1g/kg per day

 

Explanation:

  • The patient likely has Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS), a complication of advanced liver disease characterized by renal dysfunction due to splanchnic vasodilation and reduced renal perfusion.
  • HRS is diagnosed based on clinical features, including worsening renal function, low urine sodium (<10 mEq/L), and exclusion of other causes of acute kidney injury (e.g., hypovolemia, nephrotoxicity).
  • The recommended dosage of albumin infusion in HRS is 1 g/kg per day, up to a maximum of 100 g/day, to expand intravascular volume and improve renal perfusion.
  • This is used in combination with vasoconstrictors like terlipressin or norepinephrine to reverse the underlying renal vasoconstriction.
  • Higher doses (e.g., 2-5 g/kg/day) are avoided due to risks such as pulmonary edema.

 

Treatment of Hepatorenal syndrome:

  • Discontinue diuretics
  • Albumin infusion- 1 g/kg per day
  • Vasoconstrictors-Terlipressin, Low-dose norepinephrine
  • Midodrine (an α-agonist), along with octreotide and intravenous albumin
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of Type 1 hepatorenal syndrome?

choices.text: Doubling of serum creatinine over 2 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) High urinary sodium

 

Explanation:

In Type 1 HRS, urinary sodium excretion is low.

 

Types of Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS):

Type 1 HRS

Type 2 HRS

 
  • Doubling of the serum creatinine to at least greater than 2.5 or a decrease in the creatinine clearance by half or more over a two-week period. (Option A ruled out)
  • Urine output of less than 500mL/day (Option B ruled out)
  • Normal urine sediment (Option C ruled out)
  • Low urinary sodium excretion (Option D)
  
  • Stable
  • Better prognosis
  • Less severe kidney injury
  • Diuretic-resistant ascites

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a long history of cirrhosis presents to the clinic with worsening shortness of breath over the past few months. He reports that his breathlessness worsens when standing and improves when lying down. Physical examination reveals spider angiomas. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. A contrast-enhanced echocardiogram (bubble study) is performed, and delayed bubbles are seen in the left atrium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepatopulmonary syndrome

 

Explanation:

The patient's history of chronic liver disease(cirrhosis), positional dyspnea (platypnea-orthodeoxia), the presence of spider angiomas, and hypoxemia are classic findings in hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS).

 

Hepatopulmonary Syndrome (HPS): It is defined as reduced arterial oxygen saturation due to dilated pulmonary vasculature in the presence of advanced liver disease or portal hypertension.

Clinical Features
  • Characterised by the triad of:
    • Liver disease
    • Intrapulmonary vascular dilatation
    • Arterial hypoxemia
  • PaO2 less than 80 mm Hg while breathing in room air.
  • Platypnoea: Worsening of dyspnea when moving from a supine to an upright position.
  • Orthodeoxia: Decrease in PaO2 of more than 5% or more than 4 mm Hg when moving from supine to upright.
  • Portal hypertension
  • Diffuse telangiectasia/Spider naevi
  • Cyanosis
  • Fatigue and clubbing

Complications
  • Refractory hepatopulmonary syndrome.
  • Severe post-transplant hypoxemia.
  • Post-transplant portopulmonary hypertension.

 

Atelectasis (Option B):

  • Presents with localized lung findings such as decreased breath sounds, dullness to percussion and potentially an opaque area on a chest X-ray.
  • There is no positional dyspnea or bubble study findings associated with atelectasis.

 

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (Option C):

  • Present with a history of smoking, chronic cough, and progressive shortness of breath without the positional changes described in this patient.
  • The bubble study result is inconsistent with COPD.

 

Recurrent pulmonary emboli (Option D):

  • Present with sudden-onset shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain and sometimes hemoptysis.
  • A bubble study would not show the delayed appearance of bubbles in the left atrium seen in HPS.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes intrapulmonary shunting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS)

 

Explanation:

  • HPS leads to intrapulmonary shunting due to intrapulmonary vascular dilations, where blood bypasses the alveoli, resulting in poor oxygen exchange and hypoxemia.

 

Hepatopulmonary Syndrome (HPS): It is defined as reduced arterial oxygen saturation due to dilated pulmonary vasculature in the presence of advanced liver disease or portal hypertension.

Two types of HPS:

  • Type I: Dilatation of vessels at the precapillary levels near gas exchange units of the lungs. Supplemental O2 increases PaO2 in this type of HPS.
  • Type II: Larger vessel dilatation causes arteriovenous shunts away from the lungs' gas exchange units; supplemental O2 does not help.

 

Etiopathogenesis

HPS is most commonly associated with chronic liver disease or cirrhosis.

  • Liver disease: Chronic liver conditions like cirrhosis trigger systemic inflammation, releasing vasodilatory substances.
  • Nitric oxide (NO) and other vasodilators: increased NO causes intrapulmonary vascular dilatation. These dilated vessels result in abnormal oxygenation as blood bypasses the alveoli without adequate gas exchange, leading to shunt-like physiology.
  • Imbalance in angiogenic factors: Dysregulation of vascular growth factors such as endothelin-1 and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) promotes abnormal vascular remodeling in the lungs.
  • Ventilation-perfusion mismatch: The dilated pulmonary vessels result in a mismatch between areas of ventilation and blood flow, reducing the lung’s ability to oxygenate blood efficiently.

Clinical Features
  • Characterised by a triad of:
    • Liver disease
    • Intrapulmonary vascular dilatation
    • Arterial hypoxemia
  • PaO2 less than 80 mm Hg while breathing in room air.
  • Platypnoea: Worsening of dyspnea when moving from a supine to an upright position.
  • Orthodeoxia: Decrease in PaO2 of more than 5% or more than 4 mm Hg when moving from supine to upright.
  • Portal hypertension
  • Diffuse telangiectasia/Spider naevi
  • Cyanosis
  • Fatigue and clubbing

 

Portopulmonary hypertension (Option B): Causes elevated pulmonary artery pressures but does not result in intrapulmonary shunting. The pathology is related to increased vascular resistance, not shunting.

 

Recurrent pulmonary emboli (Option C): Causes vascular obstruction, leading to ventilation-perfusion mismatch (dead space), not intrapulmonary shunting.

 

Pneumonia (Option D):  Can cause impaired gas exchange and fluid accumulation in alveoli, but this results in ventilation-perfusion mismatch, not the intrapulmonary shunting seen in HPS.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis presents with worsening dyspnea.Physical examination reveals clubbing and cyanosis, which worsen when the patient sits upright and decrease in oxygen saturation when the patient changes position from supine to upright.Which of the following is considered the gold standard diagnostic method for confirming this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bubble contrast echocardiography

 

Explanation:

  • Bubble contrast echocardiography is the gold standard diagnostic test for hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS).
  • Hepatopulmonary Syndrome (HPS): It is defined as reduced arterial oxygen saturation due to dilated pulmonary vasculature in the presence of advanced liver disease or portal hypertension.

Diagnosis
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG): Demonstrates hypoxemia with a low partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂).
  • Contrast-enhanced echocardiography (bubble study): Gold standard for diagnosing intrapulmonary vascular dilatations. Bubbles from injected saline will bypass the lung's capillaries and appear in the left atrium after a delay (delayed bubbles).
  • Pulmonary angiography: Diagnose and distinguish type I and type II HPS.
  • 99mTc-labeled macroaggregated albumin scan: Can show intrapulmonary shunting where labeled particles bypass the lungs and accumulate in systemic organs such as the brain or kidneys.
  • Chest X-ray or CT scan
  • Transesophageal Echocardiogram
  • Pulmonary function tests

Differential diagnoses
  • Portopulmonary hypertension
  • Atelectasis
  • Recurrent pulmonary emboli
  • Atrial septal defect
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Pneumonia

Treatment
  • Liver transplantation: The definitive treatment, as it addresses the underlying liver disease. It has been shown to reverse pulmonary vascular abnormalities and improve oxygenation over time.
  • Oxygen therapy: Supplemental oxygen can help manage hypoxemia but is only symptomatic relief.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): This procedure is used to reduce portal hypertension.
  • Pulmonary arterial coil embolization
  • No medical therapy approved for HPS.

Complications
  • Refractory hepatopulmonary syndrome.
  • Severe post-transplant hypoxemia.
  • Post-transplant portopulmonary hypertension.

 

Pulmonary Angiography (Option A): Visualizes lung blood vessels; not specific for HPS.

 

Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) (Option B): Evaluates heart structures; may miss pulmonary vascular changes.

 

Radioactive Lung Perfusion Scan (Option C): Assesses lung blood flow; does not identify intrapulmonary shunts.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings does not typically indicate alcoholic hepatitis?

choices.text: Elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to 50 U/L - 400 U/L
AST:ALT (alanine aminotransferase) ratio of more than 1.5
Absolute value of AST/ALT greater than 600 U/L

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Absolute value of AST/ALT greater than 600 U/L

 

Explanation:

An AST/ALT level greater than 600 U/L is typically more indicative of acute liver failure or other severe liver conditions, rather than alcoholic hepatitis alone.

 

Alcoholic hepatitis

  • Alcoholic hepatitis is a severe syndrome of alcoholic liver disease (ALD), characterized by rapid onset of jaundice, malaise, tender hepatomegaly, and subtle features of systemic inflammatory response.
  • 40% of the patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis die within 6 months after the onset of clinical syndrome.

 

The National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) defines alcoholic hepatitis to include the following:

  • The onset of jaundice within 60 days of heavy alcohol consumption
  • Serum bilirubin more than 3 mg/dL (Option A ruled out)
  • Elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to 50 U/L - 400 U/L (Option B ruled out)
  • AST:ALT (alanine aminotransferase) ratio of more than 1.5 (Option C ruled out)
  • Absolute value of AST/ALT typically never exceeding 500 U/L. (Option D)

questions.text: What amount of alcohol consumption is generally considered to significantly increase the risk of developing alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) More than 100 grams per day

 

Explanation:

More than 100 grams/day over a decade is considered to significantly increase the risk of developing alcoholic hepatitis.

 

Male: 40-80 grams per day develops fatty liver, and 160 grams per day for over 10 -20 years develop alcoholic hepatitis.

Female: 20 grams per day

  • Females have a higher chance of developing alcoholic liver disease.
  • Because BMI is less, alcohol distribution per unit body weight is higher.
  • Estrogen is also responsible for it.

There is a 50 % chance that a patient with alcoholic hepatitis will deteriorate into alcoholic cirrhosis.

 

Alcoholic hepatitis

  • Alcoholic hepatitis is a severe syndrome of alcoholic liver disease (ALD), characterized by rapid onset of jaundice, malaise, tender hepatomegaly, and subtle features of systemic inflammatory response.

 

The National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) defines alcoholic hepatitis to include the following:

  • The onset of jaundice within 60 days of heavy alcohol consumption
  • Serum bilirubin more than 3 mg/dL
  • Elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to 50 U/L - 400 U/L
  • AST:ALT (alanine aminotransferase) ratio of more than 1.5
  • Absolute value of AST/ALT typically never exceeding 500 U/L.

 

Etiology:

 

Risk Factors:

  • Alcohol Consumption: High and prolonged alcohol intake, typically more than 100 grams/day for men and 20g/day for women over a decade.
  • High BMI
  • Female sex
  • 40-60 years of age
  • Genetic Factors: Genetic variant of patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3).
  • Obesity
  • non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) or viral hepatitis.

 

Stages of Alcoholic Hepatitis:

Stage

Description

Mild Alcoholic Hepatitis

Minimal liver inflammation with few symptoms.Mild elevation of liver enzymes.

Moderate Alcoholic Hepatitis

Increased liver inflammation with symptoms such as jaundice, abdominal pain and elevated liver enzymes.

Severe Alcoholic Hepatitis

Significant inflammation, liver failure, and complications like coagulopathy, ascites, and encephalopathy.

Cirrhosis

Long-term consequence of repeated episodes of alcoholic hepatitis leading to irreversible liver damage and scarring (cirrhosis).

Correct Answer: C) Mallory-Denk bodies

 

Explanation:

Mallory-Denk bodies: These are characteristic of alcoholic hepatitis.

 

Alcoholic hepatitis

  • Alcoholic hepatitis is a severe syndrome of alcoholic liver disease (ALD), characterized by rapid onset of jaundice, malaise, tender hepatomegaly, and subtle features of systemic inflammatory response.

 

The National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) defines alcoholic hepatitis to include the following:

  • The onset of jaundice within 60 days of heavy alcohol consumption
  • Serum bilirubin more than 3 mg/dL
  • Elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to 50 U/L - 400 U/L
  • AST:ALT (alanine aminotransferase) ratio of more than 1.5


 

Pathophysiology:

Alcohol Metabolism
  • Ethanol is primarily metabolized in the liver by enzymes, particularly alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1).
  • This metabolism produces acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate, which can cause cellular damage.

Oxidative Stress
  • The metabolism of alcohol generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increases oxidative stress within liver cells.
  • This oxidative damage leads to lipid peroxidation, protein modifications, and DNA damage, contributing to hepatocyte injury and inflammation.

Inflammatory Response
  • Alcohol consumption stimulates the activation of immune cells (e.g., Kupffer cells) leading to the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6).
  • These cytokines promote inflammation and can further damage hepatocytes.

Altered Lipid Metabolism
  • Alcohol disrupts normal lipid metabolism, leading to fat accumulation in liver cells (steatosis).
  • This accumulation can progress to steatohepatitis, where inflammation and liver cell injury occur.

Fibrosis and Cirrhosis
  • Chronic inflammation and injury stimulate the activation of hepatic stellate cells, which produce collagen and lead to fibrosis.
  • Over time, repeated injury can result in cirrhosis, characterized by scarring and loss of normal liver architecture.

 

Histopathology:

The classical histological features include:

 

  • Mallory-Denk bodies: Cytoplasmic inclusions composed of aggregated intermediate filaments particularly keratin (CK8/18) and other proteins.
  • Steatosis
  • Hepatocellular ballooning representing steatohepatitis
  • Cholestasis
  • Chicken-wire fibrosis
  • Cirrhosis in severely cases
  • Neutrophilic and lymphocytic infiltration

 

Russell bodies (Option A):

  • These are eosinophilic globules found in plasma cells, associated with conditions like multiple myeloma and chronic inflammatory states, not alcoholic hepatitis

Dutcher bodies (Option B):

  • These are found in the nuclei of plasma cells and are associated with multiple myeloma.
  • They are not related to liver pathology.

Kamino bodies (Option D):

  • These are found in the liver and are associated with conditions like Wilson’s disease.
  • They are not characteristic of alcoholic hepatitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents with jaundice and altered sensorium. Laboratory tests reveal elevated bilirubin, AST > ALT, hypoalbuminemia, and prolonged PT/INR. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of the presence of hepatic encephalopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Asterixis

 

Explanation:

Asterixis (flapping tremors) is a classical physical examination finding highly suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy.

Hepatic encephalopathy:

Portosystemic encephalopathy is a serious complication of chronic liver disease and is broadly defined as an alteration in mental status and cognitive function occurring in the presence of liver failure.

 

Clinical features:

  • Mental status changes can occur rapidly in acute liver failure.
  • Brain edema is common, with gray matter swelling linked to severe encephalopathy.
  • Cerebral herniation is a serious complication of brain edema.
  • Treatment for brain edema includes: Mannitol (osmotic diuretic) and Judicious use of intravenous fluids to avoid worsening edema.
  • In cirrhosis, encephalopathy is often triggered by hypokalemia, infection, increased protein intake, or volume depletion.
  • Symptoms include confusion, personality changes, violent behavior, or excessive sleepiness, making the patient difficult to manage or rouse.
  • Asterixis: A flapping tremor seen in hepatic encephalopathy.
    • Elicited by having the patient extend arms and bend wrists back (producing a “liver flap”).
  • Other features like hyperbilirubinemia, ascites or gynaecomastia are suggestive of a liver pathology but not indicative of Hepatic encephalopathy.

 

Alcoholic hepatitis Clinical features:

General
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Fever, malaise, jaundice, history of alcohol intake + (at least within last 8 weeks before symptom onset)

Abdominal
  • Right upper quadrant pain, tender hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites
  • Caput medusae: enlarged veins radiating from the umbilicus
  • Bleeding varices (portal hypertension)

Dermatological
  • Spider angioma, palmar erythema, ecchymosis

Reproductive
  • Gynaecomastia, gonadal atrophy, loss of libido, amenorrhea

Neurological
  • Peripheral neuropathy: tingling and numbness usually over feet
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: Ophthalmoplegia, confusion, ataxia + anterograde amnesia
  • Hepatic encephalopathy: Asterixis (most prominent finding), altered sensorium, sleep disturbances, lethargy

Others
  • Dupuytren’s contracture, temporal muscle wasting, parotid gland enlargement

 

Stages of alcohol induced liver injury:

1) Steatosis

2) Steatohepatitis

3) Cirrhosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a long history of heavy alcohol use presents with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal distension. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, spider angiomas, and ascites. What is the most specific investigation to diagnose his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) AST/ALT ratio

 

Explanation:

History of alcohol use with features of liver failure is suggestive of Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) and the most specific test to diagnose is AST/ALT ratio ≥ 2: 1.

 

Alcoholic liver disease LFT:

AST (Aspartate aminotransferase)

Non-specific ; ↑ (<300-400)

ALT (Alanine aminotransferase)

Specific for liver injury ; ↑ (<300-400)

AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1

Specific for ALD

ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)

Elevated in bile duct pathologies

GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase)

Non-specific marker of ALD

5’-Nucleotidase

Specific marker for bile duct pathologies

S.Bilirubin

Usually normal/mildly ↑

S.Albumin

↓ in chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)

Carbohydrate deficient transferrin (CDT)

Best serum marker for alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient succumbed to death, history revealed that the patient was admitted for liver failure 1 week back. Biopsy done is as shown below. What type of inclusions are seen in the biopsy, and what is the likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Intracytoplasmic - ALD

 

Explanation:

Biopsy shows intracytoplasmic hyaline inclusions known as Malory-Denk bodies - characteristic of Alcoholic liver disease.

 

Investigations in ALD:

Liver function tests (LFT)
  • AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1: Most specific for ALD
  • GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase): Non-specific marker of ALD
  • S.Bilirubin: Usually normal/mildly ↑

USG
  • Increased liver span, altered echotexture
  • Reversal seen in portal venous flow (Portal hypertension)

Coagulation profile
  • PT/INR: Elevated
  • (All coagulation factors are synthesized in liver except factor-VIII)

RFT
  • S.Creatinine: May be elevated in later stages (Hepato-renal syndrome)

Biopsy findings
  • Neutrophils infiltration with ballooned hepatocytes
  • Malory-Denk bodies: Intracytoplasmic hyaline inclusions
  • Bilirubin Stasis & ductular reaction
  • Chicken wire fibrosis (later stages)

 

Viral hepatitis (Option C): Councilman bodies (apoptotic cytoplasmic bodies) are seen.

questions.text:
Which among the following are components of the MELD 3.0 score?

1) Male sex

2) Albumin

3) Creatinine

4) AST

5) INR

6) Serum Na+
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 2,3,5,6

 

Explanation:

Female sex is a component of MELD 3.0 (NOT the male sex).

 

Scorings used for ALD:

MELD: (Model of End-stage Liver Disease)
  • Creatinine (3)
  • Bilirubin
  • INR (5)

MELD 3.0 :

  • Female sex
  • S. Bilirubin
  • S. Albumin (2)
  • S.Sodium (6)
  • INR
  • S.Creatinine

(mnemonic: FBASIC)

Maddrey’s Discriminant function

4.6 (PTPATIENT - PTCONTROL) + S.bilirubin

Glasgow Alcoholic Hepatitis score
  • Age
  • WBC count
  • BUN (Blood urea nitrogen)
  • S. Bilirubin
  • INR

Indications to start treatment for ALD:
  • MELD ≥ 21
  • Discriminant function ≥ 32

questions.text: A female patient who is a known alcoholic presented to OPD with jaundice and malaise. Her initial reports were PT: 24 sec (N: 11-14sec); AST: 70 Units/L (N: 10-40 U/L) ; ALT: 70 Units/L (N: 8-55 U/L); Bilirubin: 2 mg/dL (N: 0.2-1.3 mg/dL). What is the preferred management of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Oral steroids

 

Explanation:

  • History is suggestive of Alcoholic liver disease ,with Maddrey’s discriminant function score ≥ 32 is an indication to start Steroids.
  • Maddrey’s Discriminant function (DF) score: 4.6 (PTPATIENT - PTCONTROL) + S.bilirubin
  • Here, the score is 4.6 * (10) + 2 = 48 (≥ 32) and henc,e Steroids must be started along with lifestyle modifications (alcohol abstinence + dietary changes)

 

Management of Alcoholic liver disease (ALD):

Steatosis

(DF < 32 & MELD < 21)

Only lifestyle modifications:

  • Alcohol abstinence
  • Dietary changes

Steato-Hepatitis

(DF ≥ 32 / MELD ≥ 21)
  • Oral Prednisolone 32 mg/day for 4 weeks
  • Check S.Bilirubin levels 1 week after starting steroids
  • Other drugs: N-acetyl cysteine, Pentoxifylline, anti-TNFα agents

Cirrhosis (Organ failure/ Portal hypertension)
  • Liver transplant

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of Liver FibroTest?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hyaluronic acid

 

Explanation:

Hyaluronic acid is not a component of FibroTest; it is included in the Enhanced Liver Fibrosis (ELF) assay.

 

Non-invasive methods in the assessment of Liver fibrosis:

Method

Parameters

Cirrhosis

APRI (AST to platelet Ratio Index)
  • AST, Platelet count

> 1.5

ELF (Enhanced Liver Fibrosis)
  • Age
  • Hyaluronic acid
  • MMP-3 (Metalloproteinase)
  • TIMP (Tissue Inhibitor of Metalloproteinase)

> 9.3

FIB – 4
  • Age, AST, ALT, platelet count

> 3.25

FibroTest
  • Haptoglobin (Option A)
  • α2- macroglobulin
  • Apolipoprotein A1
  • γ-GT (GGT) (Option C)
  • Total bilirubin (Option D)

> 0.63

TE (Transient Elastography/ Fibrosure/ Fibroscan)
  • Wave speed generated by vibration through liver tissue is measured

> 8 kPa (Fibrosis)

> 12.5 kPa (Cirrhosis)

ARFT [Acoustic Radiation force imaging]
  • Wave speed generated by acoustic radiation through liver tissue is measured

> 1.87 m/s

Forn index

Platelet count, GGT, Age, Cholesterol

  • Forn Index = 7.811 − (3.131 × log (Platelets)) + (0.781 × log (GGT)) + (3.467 × log (Age)) − (0.014×Cholesterol)
  • Interpretation:
    • Low Forn Index (<4.2): Low probability of significant fibrosis.
    • High Forn Index (≥4.2): High probability of significant fibrosis or cirrhosis.
